intro: Ledermanniella sanagaensis, commonly known as the Sanaga mountain fern, is a rare and endemic species found in the rainforests of Central Africa. It belongs to the family Polypodiaceae and is characterized by its delicate, lance-shaped fronds. The plant typically grows on rocky outcrops or shaded forest floors, where it thrives in humid and cool conditions. Its reproductive structures, including spore-producing sorus, are located on the underside of the fronds. Due to habitat loss and limited study, it remains a poorly understood yet ecologically significant species.
